text: A dark room. We hear movement from outside. A key in the lock. The door opens, light from the hallway silhouettes Tracy as she hauls in a bag on wheels. She feels for a li on the wall and hits the switch. The lights come on.
I was sleeping! Turn that off! Tracy shuts the light.
Sorry. (pause) I’m your roommate.
My name is Laura...
A group of ten freshman sit around in a circle. One girl, Laura, holds a flashlight and says:

.--and I’m going on safari and I’m bringing with me a ROLLING PIN for Ruth, a CAR for Carrie... (everyone laughs) A JAR for Juman and a... a... shit. She stares at Tracy, unable to get her name. Tracy pipes
A TRACKING DEVICE for Tracy...
..-Right a TRACKING DEVICE for Tracy and a...LIGHTER for me, Laura. She passes the flashlight.
Tracy sits in her new dorm-room with her roommate, a girl with mousy hair and a hoodie. She watches Tracy unpack, f her bed.
Aren’t you coming to convocation?
You're going to that shit?
Yeah... isn’t everyone?
I don’t think anyone is going. Except rapists.
What? Why rapists?
Or Christians and home-schooled kids. Nobody really goes.
I think it’s just a candle lighting ceremony. (pause) How do you already know all this stuff? School hasn’t even started yet. Ruth doesn’t answer.
Tracy lingers outside the building. Kids are going inside She hesitates then decides to bag it.

head_text.subj: EXT. BROADWAY, UPPER WEST SIDE. NIGHT

text: Tracy walks aimlessly.
Tracy gets a personal sized pizza and a bowl of cereal. S picks up and inspects different items on the dessert tray doesn’t take any.
In class. Gets a paper back. She gets a B.
This is a starting point - this is what college is for, we're going to teach you how to write and think.
(frowns, to the person next to her.) A “B.” That’s so annoying.
Tracy eats by herself.
Tracy sits in front of a counselor.
Um, I have trouble with procrastinating.
Did you ever think of just getting your work in on time?
(hesitates) Yes, I have thought of that. I have trouble doing it.
Maybe you want to try a little harder?
OK, thanks. Harder? I’11 try that.
Tracy walks alone.
What comes to mind when you think of the Renaissance?
Tracy takes notes while a Southern girl talks:
I think of the Renaissance as being very plush, like a lot of velvet inlaid with jewels, brocades, that kind of thing.
Thank you... I was actually asking about literature, but that was very nice. Tracy bursts out laughing.
Tracy is kind of “dressed” for a party. There are a bunch drunk teenagers around. She sees a Friendly Looking Girl:
Is the party at the end of the hall?
Did you get an invitation?
No...
Then no.
She's being a bitch. Yes, it’s down the hall. The Friendly Looking Girl hits the Other Girl and they ru away, laughing. Tracy leaves the way she came.
Tracy sits on steps. She’s on the phone with her Mom.
I could be anywhere. It doesn’t even feel like New York. And by trying to participate I’m somehow fitting in even less. Her Mom moves through the kitchen, cleaning, putting thin away.
Aren’t you meeting friends in classes?
Mom, nobody meets friends in classes.
Oh, okay. I didn’t know.
You know the feeling of being at a party where you don’t know anybody? It’s like that the whole time.
That sounds uncomfortable.
And I can’t go to bars.
Don’t go to bars. Oh, did you get my email with the reading - do you like it?
I liked it. I think there is a darker element to what Shakespeare was saying but I liked it.
Good. Your brother is going to be playing guitar with you while you do it - is that okay?
I like David’s guitar playing.

(happily) He’s gotten good, right? I’m so excited! It’s Thanksgiving weekend so we'll have a built-in rehearsal dinner on Thursday at the house. It’ll be the first time the two families are all in the same room. Randy, Jim's sister --
Right.
She's going to make a fig and there’s a fish...and it’s on cracker. That’s one thing.
Mmm.

We're going to move all the furniture out of the living room and we changed the lyrics to Finiculi Finicula. We did the same thing at Izzy’s 60th but Izzy won't be there so it’1l feel fresh. (exhaling, playful) Oh, Trace...
(playful back) Oh, Stevie.
You know, I was very unhappy for a very long time. But I’m so glad your Dad and I stayed together until you and your brother were out of school.
I was NOT out of school. You broke up when I was a junior in high school.
On your way out of the home...
I love you Mom, don’t be worried.

I know, honey. So after you do that, Brooke will read a poem she’s written. I don’t think her brother is doing anything - which hurts my feelings, but I’m trying to be okay with it. (has an idea) You should call Brooke. She’s in New York, you know.
I’m so bad at calling people I don’t know.
I hear she’s fun.
She's like thirty living in New York with a life, she doesn’t need to hear from an eighteen year old she’s tenuously connected to. I'd be like why do I want to hang out with you?
She's going to be your sister, that doesn’t sound tenuous to me. And you have plenty to talk about - you're both doing readings at our wedding.
Aces.
You aren’t sarcastic don’t pretend to be.
Okay.
We hear a student, Nicolette, making a point:

Nothing is higher than the law. That’s the whole point - Antigone thinks she’s above the law but she’s not - like a celebrity ina car crash or something. Tracy is asleep at the seminar table. Her head hangs heav to one side.
Psst. Hey. Tracy's head jerks up and she opens her sleepy eyes. A bo Tony leans over from two chairs away.
You were asleep.
(wiping drool from her chin) Oh...thanks.  Tracy sits up straighter. She tries to focus on the discussion. Her eyes fall heavy and shut. She’s asleep again.
Tony carries a briefcase. Tracy, deciding to make her fat better, walks up to him.
That was really nice of you... waking me up.
(smiling) It takes a lot of moxie to fall asleep in a twelve person class.
Thanks. I like moxie.
I get it. It’s like I’m so grateful to be here, but why are my parents taking out loans for me to listen to that 18-year-old asshole talk? Tracy laughs.
Loans everywhere.
I was going go get frozen yogurt, want to come?
Yes but... well, I have to get somewhere by five.
Where?
Um, it’s embarrassing.
What is it?
I’m submitting a story to the Mobius Literary Society. I have to print it. (MORE )
They only take hard copies which is a kind of pretension I can get behind.
GET OUT OF TOWN SISTER! I already gave mine! Do you know how you find out if you’re in it?
They said they’d post a list -

No. The only people who check the list are people who didn’t get in - they come wake us up at night in our rooms and put pie in our face and then bring us out into the quad and make us sing and stuff.
(smiling at the thought) Yeah.

Tracy walks down to a door with Mobius on the glass. Ther a box outside with Submissions written underneath it. A g in a sweater vest sitting cross legged on the ground play jacks stares at her. She fishes into her messenger bag an puts a story in the box. She hurries away. INT. TRACY’S DORM ROOM. NIGHT Tracy lies awake in bed. We hear yelling in the hallway outside her door. Footsteps come close to her door. A shadow underneath. She tenses in great anticipation. The footsteps and chatter continue down the hall. Tracy gets up and opens her door.
The hall is empty. Bits of pie and crust on the floor. Another door opens at the end of the hall. A Tiny Girl lo out. She and Tracy meet eyes.
The Tiny Girl retreats into her room. Tracy does the same  INT. TONY’S ROOM. DAY Tony sits on his bed and Tracy sits on the floor. drink screwdrivers.
They’re self-elected douche bags.
I know, but I wanted to be one of them. I could die then.
Yeah, me too. Both I wanted to be in and I could also then die.
I heard they serve wine and cheese and they all carry breifcases.
I know, when I had my tour here, the guide was one of them and that’s why I wanted to come here.
I heard the pie stuff all night.
They got the guy next door. He doesn’t even look like a writer. 10. They both Tony indicates a breifcase from the floor. Tracy sees thi
I’m so sorry.
Do you want to trade stories?
Sure.
They both silently read each other's stories. They steal glances at one another.
I liked it!  11.
Thanks - I liked yours too.
So do you want notes?
Oh, are we - sure...
Okay, I thought the middle part sounded really fake.
Okay.
It’s just my impression.
I‘’1l work on that.
Do you have any notes for me?
Um... no.
Great. (thinks for a second) I have a car.
Tracy and Tony drive in the car.
Let’s go to the beach.
I don’t want to leave Manhattan.
Oh, why are we in your car then?

head_text.subj: EXT. UPPER MANHATTAN, BY THE HUSDON RIVER. NIGHT

text: Tracy and Tony try to burn his briefcase but it won’t cat fire. They chuck it in the water. They smoke a joint and sit on the roof of a car.  12.
We look like we’re in a song.
Tracy raises her hand.
I think the way Aristotle writes about ethics and morality is much closer to how most people think about it. Less like math, more like a story.
Tracy, feeling better about herself, cleans the room and talks to her roommate.
I think we should set up a recycling system for our trash. A lot of what we’re throwing out can be recycled. She trips over something on the floor but recovers quickl
And Ruth, I think that fan can go in the closet now, it’s 60 degrees out--
Tracy is filing with some exuberance.
You seem happy today.
I love filing! It’s satisfying.
Tracy is running to get somewhere.
Slow down, T! Tracy hits the breaks. It’s Tony. She laughs. But he’s holding Nicolette’s hand (She’s the girl from their class
Hey.  13.
Hey.
Hey.
Tracy sits in a booth by herself eating mozzarella sticks She looks at her phone. Makes a call. Her mother’s voice mail. She hangs up. She scrolls to:
She quickly presses that name...

You’ve reached Brooke Cardinas. Leave your name and number and I will get back to you at my earliest convenience. Tracy hangs up on the beep. She dips a mozzarella stick i the red sauce and shoves it into her mouth. Her phone rin She's startled.
Hello?
Hi, this Brooke Cardinas. I just got a missed call from this number.
Oh...sorry. Hi... this is Tracy Fishko, um, my mom is marrying your dad?
You're reading the sonnet.
Right! We’re doing Thanksgiving and then wedding together... Um, I go to college in the city. My mom said I should call you.
Have you eaten? Do you want to hang out?  14.
(looks at her near- finished plate) No, I haven’t. OK.
Well, do you know where Times Square is?
Tracy crosses the crowded street. Brooke is at the top of the TKTS steps. She attempts to w elegantly down the steps. It’s an entrance.
(awkwardly grand) Welcome to the Great White Way. She still hasn’t finished walking the steps. It takes a second. Tracy holds a smile. Finally, Brooke is there:
Times Square is so crazy.
Isn't it?
I don’t know anyone who lives here.
Yours truly. I got off the bus from Jersey I thought this was the cool place to live. It’s mother fucking Times Square.
Brooke lights a cigarette, takes a long drag, passes it t Tracy.
Why do you live in New York again?
College - I go to Barnard - it’s all women uptown - well, “historically” and kind of actually. But there are boys in my classes and stuff. From Columbia.  15.
You gay?
No. The Columbia girls do their best to make us feel inferior. Which it’s like “I already do.”
That’s stupid. Don’t feel inferior.
You're right, that is stupid. It’s the best someone has made her feel in a long time or Maybe ever.

head_text.subj: INT. BACKSTAGE AT A MUSIC CLUB. NIGHT

text: Brooke, wearing an orange VIP sticker on her suede jacket affixes an identical sticker to Tracy’s shirt.
I didn’t go to college.
Oh. OK.
I’m an autodidact. Do you know what that means?
Yes.

That word is one of the things I self-taught myself. CUT TO: Brooke is pulled up onstage to sing, she tries to act like she doesn’t want to and then does it. When she dances while she sings it’s a person who is pretending to free.
Brooke, Tracy and members of the band enter one of those secret bars, through the back of a pizza shop.
Tracy drinks a fancy cocktail.  16.
It has mint! CUT TO: Brooke and Tracy dance with the guys.
(dancing) What’s going on at college?
(also dancing) I don’t know, everyone’s really excited about the frozen yogurt machine in the student center.
I watched my mother die.
What?
I was with my mother while she died.
I don’t know any dead people.
That’s cool about the frozen yogurt machine. Everyone I love dies.
Brooke and Tracy enter some party in Williamsburg. The hostess hugs Brooke.
I heard you’re opening a restaurant!? WTF?!
Brooke and Tracy are in a closet - Brooke is going throug while Tracy watches her.
This bitch stole my favorite pants - they’re in here somewhere - she thinks I don’t know but I know everything. They're red.  17.
(vaguely) I’1l look here. Tracy starts going through the closet.
People are always taking my shit. My ex-friend and nemesis, Mamie- Claire, stole my ideas AND my fiance.
Shit.

She took this T-shirt idea that I had, started a company fucking sold it to J. Crew so there is that. She’s one of those people who doesn’t have any good ideas for her own life so she just steals all of mine. And then she LITERALLY stole my cats.
What were the T-shirts?
Just really hard looking flowers.
Oh my God! I bought one of those T- shirts!
Yeah, flowers with like skulls and shit. Daggers.
That’s a great one.
My fiance, Dylan, was super sexy. And so rich. But I wasn’t going to marry him.
So...wait, you broke up with Dylan? I thought she stole him?
And I never looked back. He cried so hard. Like, whiney.  18. She does an impression:
“Where are you going?” (back to herself) I was being real, but Mamie-Claire then goes and marries him. They live in Greenwich, Connecticut in some big gross house. Do you know that place?
Yeah, Greenwich, grossville.
Right? Living off of his riches and my T-shirt idea.
(instant disciple) I hate them.
I actually pity them. They have no more dreams. Tracy holds up a pair of red pants, triumphant.
These?!
I want to MARRY you! She grabs the pants, stuffs them in her purse and then ge out of the closet.
Brooke makes out with Nate, the singer. Tracy is trying n to watch. Another band member takes a picture on his iPho
Must we all document ourselves all the time? MUST WE?!
Tracy and Brooke eat pierogis in the mostly empty diner.
Is he your boyfriend? The bassist?  19.
Nate? No! My beau, Stavros, is in Greece right now. Betting against the country or something gross. Don’t tell anyone that.
(dead serious) I won’t. I’m good at keeping secrets. You’ll learn that about me.
He’s one of those people I hate except I’m in love with him. I’ve been to a Greek Orthodox Easter and I could totally see myself getting married in that kind of church. She knocks her head for wood.
You got a honey?
Nah, there’s this one guy, we got rejected together...but he’s got a girlfriend.
They all have girlfriends.
Actually I think he met me and then he got a girlfriend. (pause) This summer, at my job, one guy just sucked on my boobs all night.
(thinking aloud) My restaurant should do a pierogi. Fusion pierogi. You like yours?
(nods, stuffing a pierogi in her mouth) This is my second dinner. Brooke takes out her phone and types something.
(putting her phone back) Just a quick tweet on Twitter. (MORE )
I am VERY into social media. You have to market yourself. If you don’t know what you’re selling, no one will know how to buy it.
What are you selling?
So many things. I don’t tweet all of it. Like here are two ideas that are not on the internet. If I did a cabaret, it would be called “High Standards” and I'd sing all the standards.
Would you sing them in a higher pitch?
No, it wouldn’t be about - it’s about principles, those kinds of high standards - like one of those “string of pearls that’s why I’ma single gal” kind of show.
That’s clever.

The second idea is a television show, which I’ve read is the new novel, about a woman who is a government worker by day and a self- invented super hero by night, but like the essence of AMERICA. It’1l be it’s own mythology. I think maybe it’1ll be called Mistress America.
That sounds like she’s America’s girl on the side.
Hey, I don’t know, okay, I’m not positive, these are just some ideas.
Me too! I’m sorry, I don’t know anything, I was just throwing something out there.  21. They both laugh.
(an idea) We need a sleep-over party.
Books piled on the floor. Lots of drawings pinned to the wall. One framed piece of real art.
This apartment is technically zoned commercial but that’s fake.
It’s so stylish.
Fuck, I know, I freelance as an interior decorator. You know the Bowery Hotel?
Oh my God, yeah.
Well, if you walk about a block south. There’s a laser hair removal center that’s very hip. I did the waiting room.
Cool.
I know.
I’m leaving here in January anyway, moving to the East side if you can believe it. That’s where Stavros lives. I’m going to redo his place too. Brooke flops on her bed. Tracy lies on the couch.
I want to write short stories.
Oh, me too! Not short stories, though.
But I got rejected by the Lit Society. I’m so suggestible, like because I got rejected I think I can’t be a writer.
Why don’t you make your own Lit Society?
I wish. Mobius is a big deal at school.
You've got other stories.
(smiling) Maybe I’1l write something else and resubmit. (falling asleep, eyes closed) That was really funny when we were doctors.
Yeah, I need to cut all the negative people out of my life. I just wasn’t brought up that way.
Thank you Brooke.
You’re welcome Baby Tracy. INT. BROOKE’S APARTMENT. NEXT MORNING Brooke is on the phone with Stavros:

My sweetheart I miss you so much - I can’t wait for you to see the chairs I’ve picked out - we start renovation Monday! It’s so exciting. I’ve been going there just to sit in the mess I love it so much. Tracy wakes up a little with the noise.  23.
Right. Did you see the lease it was 400 pages! I wish you would just come home already so I can suck your dick in our new restaurant! She pads into the kitchen.
(to Tracy) Can you start the coffee, please?
(looking at the coffee maker) I don’t know how...

(a little sharply) Yes, you do. Don’t be incompetent. If you spent two seconds with a coffee maker you'd figure it out. You just aren’t trying hard enough. Brooke retreats into the hall, still talking to her boyfriend.
Um, where are you going.

head_text.subj: DUH COMMUNAL BATHROOM DO YOU WANT

text: (to the phone) Are you still there?
Sorry. Are you... mad at me?
CUT TO: Tracy and Brooke drink coffee at her table/desk.

We have four investors including me. I’m what you call a principal investor. Stavros is putting in my share - but I insisted that it be my assets on the line because I want him to know I have skin in the game. I’11 pay him back of course once we start making a profit.  24.
We never went to restaurants growing up - it wasn’t part of our lives.
(immediately offended) That’s a shitty thing to say to me.

I didn’t mean - I know people will come to yours. (trying to contextualize) It’s so weird to think that every restaurant I see is the result of some person going “I think I want to start a restaurant.”
That’s not weird. That’s everything. Tracy starts to write something down in a notebook. Brook is curious:
What are you doing?
I’m actually... it’s embarrassing.
What?
I’m writing down what I said.
You are noting yourself?
Yeah... I guess so.
I’ve noticed something about myself that would make a good character in a story.
Oh yeah?  25.
But I’m going to save it in case I want to use it in something I write.
The commercial streets have that peculiar weekend morning vibe. Tracy is in her outfit from the night before. Brook is in full workout clothes.
High five, sister. That was an AMAZING night.
Yeah, it was... (blurts it out) The best of my life.

(looking at her phone) I gotta go. Brooke abruptly hugs her and leaves. Tracy watches her go for one second and then also turns to go. She’s disappoin but she doesn’t know why. INT. TRACY’S DORM ROOM. MORNING Tracy enters and goes right to her computer. Tracy is typing very quickly, still in her jacket, her ba still on her shoulder. She hesitates, trying to remember something.
What did she...say? Talking while she types.
Right! “He’s one of those people that I hate except I’m in love with him.”
(still sleeping) Shut up please. CUT TO: Brooke Cardinas being typed into a Google search.  26.
Meadow DeRiggi lived exactly how a young woman should live who wants to spend her youth well. CUT TO: Brooke’s Twitter page. Random photos of Brooke.
She did everything and nothing and spent time like I always mean to - purposefully. CLOSE on Tracy’s short story. CLOSE on a Society page photo. CLOSE on Brooke’s Soul Cycle Teacher bio.
Tracy tries to go to the secret bar, can’t get in.
Her beauty was that rare kind that made you want to look more like yourself not like her.
Tracy gets in, but it’s not a good band and there aren’t lot of people there.
She sang with the band and knew everyone and didn't owe anyone anything and couldn't pay up even if she did.
Tracy sees a blonde in red pants. She brightens. As she gets closer, it’s not Brooke.
Being around Meadow was like being in New York City - it made you want to find life, not hide from it.
(embarrassed) Sorry.  27.
That’s OK.
Tony and Nicolette and Tracy sit at a study table.
Where were you last night, did you get my texts?
You text her? You texted her?
About work.
I went to check out this downtown band at this downtown bar. Two freshmen girls approach.
Do you guys know how long you’1l need this table?
A long time, dude.
(sighs) Fine. They leave.
Who were you with?
Myself.
(to Tony) When you said you were checking the scores, were you texting her? Are you sexting?
It’s a place my sister showed me.
You don’t have a sister.  28.
I do. Or I will. When my mom gets married at Thanksgiving.
Why don’t you just text her a picture of your balls.
Nicolette! Tracy smooths over some stapled pages from her bag. We se the title: Mistress America.
What’s that?
It's a new story I wrote. I’m going to resubmit to the Lit Society.
Wait, you wrote another one already? You printed it on onion skin?
You can read it if you want. Here-- She hands him a copy - he looks at it.
(to Nicolette) Tracy writes about fighter pilots.
I’m past that stuff now. This one is more autobiographical documentary.
OK. I'd totally give you notes.
No, I don’t want notes -- but I thought about it and I actually do have notes for you.
Oh...sure.  29.

You write like you are imitating someone who is free and wild and it is so WEIRD because you aren’t at all and it made me uncomfortable and I think it would make EVERYONE uncomfortable. And also, stop trying to be funny because you aren’t funny so it just adds to the awkwardness. And it could be 30% shorter, easy.
(unsure) OK. Thanks. Tracy gets up and leaves. Passes the freshmen girls.
It’s open, bitches. They don’t need it anymore.

Tracy returns to the door with Mobius on the glass. The s guy in a sweater vest is whittling a piece of wood. He bl on it as he whittles. Tracy places her story in the Submissions box. She hurries away.
Brooke is in the front of the classroom, on a bike with a headphone and a bandana. Tracy enters, wearing jeans and a button down. Brooke smiles.
(too loudly) Hey Baby Tracy! Brooke indicates a bike with a nod of her head. Tracy sha her head emphatically: No. Brooke nods, Yes. CUT TO: Tracy is on a bike sweating an uncomfortable amou
(to her cycling class)

head_text.subj: HOW YOU DO ANYTHING IS HOW YOU DO

text: (and now in a low voice) I know not enough people have told you that you’re amazing. I know that that’s true.  30. Everyone loves her, she’s sort of great as a cycling instructor.
Tracy is really sweaty, still.
You did great!
I feel like I just went swimming in my clothes.
I’m glad you came.
You are?!
Shit, I have to shower and change, I’m late for an appointment.
Brooke gets her hair blown out - Tracy sits beside her an looks at Brooke in the mirror.
This air conditioning is making me freezing.
Brooke, in a conservative blouse and suit, pearl earrings heels, holding a briefcase walks with Tracy in her jeans. She towers over her. (Midnight Cowboy shot.)
They stop outside the restaurant. Brooke is suddenly very nervous. She smooths down her blouse, her hair.
(pulling down the sides of her skirt) God, I’m packed into this pencil skirt. How do I look?
You look beautiful.  31.
But do I look professional? (pause) I get really nervous with the investors. I’m usually fine with wealthy people, it’s just when I need something from them.
No, it’s the opposite - they need you and your restaurant.
Stavros usually does this stuff. Maybe I shouldn’t do it. I’m not good at it.
(sincerely) I think you can do anything. Everything. Brooke nods.

Right. Kind and fearless. She goes inside. CUT TO: Tracy watches through the window. Brooke sits amongst three men in suits and another powerful looking w in a suit. She makes them laugh. CUT TO: Brooke meets Tracy outside. Brooke looks relieved
It’s amazing how much of business is just stating the same things over and over again.
Your body language looked very self- confident.
Thanks. You make me feel really... Smart. Tracy beams.
Wanna see it?  32.

head_text.subj: INT. EMPTY RESTAURANT SPACE, BROOKLYN. DAY

text: Brooke shows Tracy the space. During the scene, Brooke is changing out of her “lawyer outfit” into her “tutoring outfit” - skinny jeans, T-shirt and Converse.

(gesturing) The front part would be like a shop during the day - like a general store or a really nice bodega - candy from Europe - on Monday we start demo and we open in April. She knocks her head for “wood.” She leads Tracy through t back -

We'd also have cooking classes. Maybe cut hair. It would be like a community center and restaurant and store all in one. It would be the place that you would, like, LOVE to be. I wish I had something like this when I was growing up.
Yeah, suburban New Jersey isn’t great with this kind of stuff.
Each plate would be different. Let me show you.
Can I be a waitress here? Brooke opens a box.
See! Look at all these plates!
(taking in the whole thing) Holy shit you have a lot of plates.
I started collecting them so long ago - I didn’t know why and now I have a why! Tracy's been touching all of them.  33.
This is going to be a great restaurant.
I know!
Are you going to cook, too?

(shakes her head) I‘1l help create the menu and pitch in when needed. I’m not trained, but I’m an enthusiastic home cook. I always used to cook with my Mom. That’s the name of the restaurant. Mom's. Possessive.
(trying it out) “Let’s go to Mom’s for dinner.” Yeah, it totally works. (tries again) Can I be a waitress here?

I want the whole deal - I want the dead-on-my-feet-wake-up-and-I 'm- forty. I’ve spent my whole life chasing after things and knocking at doors and I’m tired of running towards people. I want to be the place that people COME to. I want to make a home for all the knockers and runners - I’m good at that. I'm happy with that. I keep the hearth. That’s a word, right? Hearth?
Brooke is going in to tutor. The final thing she does is on her fake glasses.
Don’t I look like a cute smart graduate student?
Yeah!  34.
I tutor junior high because I didn’t get high enough SAT scores to do SAT tutoring, but you make way more money doing SAT. So, I’m taking the SAT’s AGAIN so I can make inroads into that racket.
I’ve always been a good test taker.
None of this will be necessary when the restaurant is up and running, but I’m good that way, curating my employment. Brooke is rifling through her purse.
So, um, should I - just wait here or...
Oh! I thought you had to go back to school.
Right. I should....
Do you want to stay?
I mean, if you don’t mind...
Yeah, I’d invite you in but Peggy's Mom just got institutionalized for bi-polar disorder and shit’s pretty real upstairs. Tutoring is like 60% middle school math and 40% I know too much about them.
That’s okay, then, I’1ll just go - Brooke hands her keys, not listening to her.

Tracy's sleeping. She looks peaceful. We HEAR a door open footsteps and suddenly a pie is jammed in her face. Tracy screams. And screams. And screams. The members of the Mobius Lit Club all stop in their trac The boy in the sweater vest says:
You're in.

CLOSE on The Mobius Literary Journal. Tracy opens it up t her story: Mistress America by Tracy Fishko. She reads it again in the magazine.
Tree lighting ceremony. Tracy walks under the lit trees.

I don’t want to join Mobius. I've had enough rejection.

It’s not for Mobius. I quit the briefcase club. You were right, they're self-appointed douche bags. I’m starting my own zine and I’m not saying you’re in, but I am saying I'd be very interested in getting your and Nicolette’s application. Tony stands, he thinks about this for a moment.
I'll fix us some screwdrivers.

Tracy goes by the restaurant. For Let. Tracy goes to Soul Cycle, a different instructor. Thanksgiving Day parade. Tracy watches the floats alone. INT. BROOKE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. HALLWAY. AFTERNOON Tracy knocks on a door. Kareem, in a tie, answers.
Hello.  108.
Hi - I’m sorry to bother you on Thanksgiving, but I met you once - I went through your window? It was in the middle of the night...
Yeah...
I was with Brooke.
You're her sister, right?
Well, I was going to be. Do you have a number for her? The old one isn’t working...
I don’t--

Anyway - I was going to ask you: do you know where she went? Kareem indicates for Tracy to follow him. She passes thro a cozy apartment. The table is set for the holiday. A couple of kids run through.
Her front door is still bolted shut. They reach the window. Kareem opens it.
She's upstairs.

Tracy climbs the fire escape. She gets to the top window looks through the glass. The place is mostly empty save for stacked boxes and suitcases. Brooke walks into the room and places some books into a b She wears her red pants. Tracy knocks. Brooke looks up an comes to the window. She and Tracy stare at each other through the glass.  109.
(through the glass) Hi.
Hi.
Can I come in? CUT TO: Tracy sits on some boxes watching Brooke move aro packing.
You're leaving?
In a couple of hours. I’m going to try my luck out west.
You're going today? On Thanksgiving?
New York isn’t the New York I used to know. There’s too much construction. Maybe LA is my lady. In LA I qualify as well-read.
I wanted to say--
I know you’re sorry.
I’m not really that sorry.
You're not?
No.
Oh then fuck this. Brooke opens the window again.
No, no wait... (pause) I looked for you.  110.
I’ve been around.
Are you OK? Like, financially?
Yeah. Mamie-Claire gave me what would have been my share of our T- shirt profits. It was just enough to pay off my debts and get out of town.
What will you do in LA?

I don’t know. I think I’m sick. And I don’t know if my ailment has a name - it’s just me sitting and staring at the internet or the television for long periods of time interspersed by trying to not do that and then lying about what I’ve been doing. Then I’1l get so excited about something that the excitement overwhelms me and I can’t sleep or do anything - and then I just am in love with everything but can’t figure out how to make myself work in the world.
I think I have that too.

I wish we lived in feudal times when your position in the world couldn’t change. If you were a king or a peasant you had to just be happy with who you were. (pause) But...wait! Brooke looks inside an open box. She finds a piece of pap and hands it to Tracy. CLOSE: SAT results. 2200.
You can tutor SAT’s now.  111.
Well, I thought I might actually go to college. I’m not an amputee.
(confused) Right.
I filled out a couple of applications. I wrote my college essay all about you.
(apprehensive) Really?
Oh snap! No. It’s about my mom. But I had you there.
Yeah. Brooke goes into the other room to retrieve more books.
I let Mamie-Claire and Dylan keep the cats. It’s like, I gave thema chance for a better life, better than I could have provided for them.
The cats went from stolen to given because you changed your mind.

Don’t put that in a story. Not because I care but because it’s not a very good observation. Tracy sees the Mobius Literary Journal (the one with her story) inside an open box. She’s about to say something, thinks better of it. Brooke reenters and tosses books int the box.
You know what’s funny... I’m not even done with my first semester of college.  112.
This won’t even be your big “college story.”
I think it’1ll always be pretty big. Brooke hesitates, emotional for a second. She musses Trac hair like a kid.
Well, thanks for stopping by, but I have more packing to do before Kareem and I break down the front door.
It’ll be hard for me not to look at New York and think of you somewhere in it. Brooke shrugs.
Yeah. Tracy moves toward the window. She looks back at her frie
Hey Brooke... Brooke turns around.
It’s not going to be as great as what my mom and your dad were planning, but... Do you want to have Thanksgiving with me?
We watch Brooke and Tracy through the window eating piero for Thanksgiving.
Meadow had made rich fat women less fat and rich stupid kids less stupid and lame rich men less lame. And she wanted so badly to be on the other side - to be fat and stupid and lame and rich. (MORE )

But what she couldn't see most of all, more than she couldn't see that she was never going to get the restaurant, was that those people were nothing compared to her. They were matches to her bonfire. She was the last cowboy - all romance and failure. The world was changing and her kind didn’t have anywhere to go. Being a beacon of hope for lesser people is a lonely business. And as Brooke and Tracy talk and reminisce and laugh, we TO BLACK.
